fields.descriptive_line: John Talman, after Leilo Orsi and Ciro Ferri. Design for an altar with insets in upper panel showing the hooking of a fish, and in lower panel showing three saints etc. British, probably after Italian original, c.1710.
fields.physical_description: Design for an altar with an inset in the upper panel showing the hooking a fish. The lower inset shows the Madonna and Child worshipped by St Francis, St Lucy and St Lawrence. This group is borrowed from Lelio Orsi's Madonna della Ghiara at Reggio Emilia.  The altar piece is copied from a design by Ciro Ferri.
fields.location: Prints & Drawings Study Room, room WS, case R, shelf 35, box R
Prints & Drawings Study Room, room WS

fields.name: Prints & Drawings Study Room, room WS

fields.public_access_description:
Design for an altar with an inset in the upper panel showing the hooking of a fish. The lower inset shows the Madonna and Child worshipped by St Francis, St Lucy and St Lawrence. This group is borrowed from Lelio Orsi's Madonna della Ghiara at Reggio Emilia.  The altar piece is copied from a design by Ciro Ferri.

John Talman (1677-1726)  was the son of the celebrated architect William Talman. From about 1698 he was employed by his father to help assemble material for his extensive collection of architectural drawings, prints and books. A keen traveller, he went  to the Continent twice in search of acquisitions. He visited the northern Netherlands, France, Germany and Italy, and he made numerous watercolour copies of altarpieces and churches in Rome. 

Talman was back in England in 1715. He was a founder-member of the Tavern Society, London, which later became the Society of Antiquaries, and he was appointed its first director. Like his father, Talman believed in the elevating purpose of art and in the use of art collections for the public good. Although his will indicates that he had wanted his vast collection (which contained over 32,000 prints and drawings), to go to Trinity College, Cambridge, he later changed his mind and instructed that it should be sold for the benefit of his children. A portion of the collection was nonetheless given outright to the Society of Antiquaries, who acquired further items from the auction in London on 19 April 1727. 

This drawing is part of an album in the V&A collections that contain drawings made by Talman and other artists. Talman intended to publish it for the benefit and enjoyement of a wider public.
fields.bibliography: Ward-Jackson, Peter, Italian Drawings. Volume II. 17th-18th century, London, 1979, p. 110 The following is the full text of the entry: The Madonna and Child worshipped by St Francis, St Lucy and St Lawrence. Inlaid in the frame of an altar drawn by a different hand Inscribed underneath in ink 'Ciro Ferri' Pen and ink and blue wash 6 ¼ x 4 ¼ (158 x 108) E.335 PROVENANCE J. Talman; Francis St John; Marquess of Cholmondeley (in the album described in Appendix A and in Lugt 2462) The group of the Virgin and Child is borrowed from Lelio Orsi's well known Madonna della Ghiara at Reggio Emilia. The altar-piece is copied (possibly by Talman) from a design by Ciro Ferri which is reproduced in an engraving in <i>Disegni di vari altari e cappelle nelle chiese di Roma... date in luce da Gio. Ciacomo de Rossi ..., n.d. Victoria and Albert Museum, Department of Engraving, Illustration and Design and Department of Paintings, Accessions 1937, London: Board of Education, 1938. The full text of the record is as follows: 'TALMAN, John (1677-1726). Designs for altars and a door, some with inset drawings for picture panels. Probably modified copies of Italian originals. c.1710. Pen and ink, wash and water-colour. E.314, 322, 323, 325-332, 335, 339, 340-1937 From the collections of J. Talman (1677-1728) and Francis St. John. Design for altar with inset in upper panel probably by J. Talman, showing a saint lying stretched on a bed, with landscape scene in distance. Pen and ink, wash and water-colour. E.314-1937 Design for altar in semicircular apse, in the ceiling of which appear the symbols associated with the Barberini family, amid foliage. Inscribed in pen on back V. Pen and ink and wash. E.322-1937 Design for altar in the style of the middle of the 16th century with inset showing the Archangel Michael, attributed to Ventura di Salimbeni. Inscribed in pen in the hand of Francis St. John E collectione Jacobi Thornhill Equitis Pictoris Historiar & c. Inscribed on inset Ventura Salembeni and on back of inset di ventura Salembini Pen and ink (inset, pen and ink and wash). E.323-1937 Design for altar in semicircular apse. Inscribed in pen on back V. Pen and ink and wash. E.325-1937 Design for altar with inset probably by J. Talman, showing Christ questioning the doctors in the temple. Inscribed in pen with scale in feet and inches, and on back V. Pen and ink and wash. E.326-1937 Designs for a doorway and altar on separate sheets within one mount. Inscribed in pen on back of E.327 P and on back of E.228 V. Pen and ink, wash and water-colour. E.327, 328-1937 Design for an altar with inset showing a female saint. Inscribed in pen on back V. Pen and ink, wash and water-colour. E.329-1937 Design for an altar. Inscribed in pen on back V. Pen and ink and wash. E.330-1937 Design for an altar and flanking doorways, with traces of previous inset. Inscribed in pen on back V. Pen and ink and wash. E.331-1937 Design for an altar. Inscribed in pen on back F.F. Pen and ink, wash and water-colour. E.332-1937 Design for an altar with insets in upper panel showing the hooking of a fish, and in lower panel showing three saints etc., by or after Ciro Ferri. Inscribed in pen, back and front, attributing the lower inset to Ciro Ferri, and in pencil on back H. Pen and ink and wash. E.335-1937 Design for an altar. Inscribed in pen on back V. Pen and ink and wash. E.339-1937 Design for an altar with inset in water-colour, probably by J. Talman, showing the repentant Magdalene. Pen and ink, wash and water-colour. E.340-1937'
fields.credit: From the collections of J. Talman and Francis St. John.
